1 #include <pses_odometry/ForwardKinematics.h>
2 
3 /* This empty constructor for ForwardKinematics requries to call setK() to
4  *set distance
5  * between front and back axis als input arguments. That means the starting
6  * postion is always (0 ,0 ,0) and orientation theta = 0.
7  */
8 ForwardKinematics::ForwardKinematics()
9 {
10  PI = std::acos(-1);
11  initT = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
12  T.push_back(Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity());
13  prevT = initT;
14  currentPosition = std::vector<double>(3, 0);
15 }
16 /* This constructor for ForwardKinematics only requries the distance
17  * between front and back axis als input arguments. That means the starting
18  * postion is always (0 ,0 ,0) and orientation theta = 0.
19  */
20 ForwardKinematics::ForwardKinematics(double k) : k(k)
21 {
22  PI = std::acos(-1);
23  initT = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
24  T.push_back(Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity());
25  prevT = initT;
26  currentPosition = std::vector<double>(3, 0);
27 }
28 /* This method calculates the momentaneous center of curvature for a
29  *vehicle
30  * with a certain size and ackermann-drive. The ICC is proportional to the
31  * steering angle alpha.
32  */
33 std::pair<double, double> ForwardKinematics::calcICC(double alpha)
34 {
35  double x = -k / std::tan(alpha);
36  double y = -k;
37  return std::make_pair(x, y);
38 }
39 /* A utility function to remove values very close to zero, since numerical
40  * sine
41  * and cosine functions sometimes do not equal 0 for certain radiant values.
42  */
43 double ForwardKinematics::flattenZeros(double value)
44 {
45  return (std::fabs(value) < 0.000001) ? 0 : value;
46 }
47 /* Since ackermann driven cars always travel on circular lines (except when
48  * they
49  * are driving straight forward), this method calculates the radius of those
50  * circular
51  * trajectories, with the ICC as center.
52 */
53 double ForwardKinematics::calcRadius(std::pair<double, double> ICC)
54 {
55  return std::sqrt(ICC.first * ICC.first + ICC.second * ICC.second);
56 }
57 /* This calculates how many radians the car has moved around the ICC with
58  * a certain radius.
59  */
60 double ForwardKinematics::calcTheta(double distance, double radius)
61 {
62  return distance / radius;
63 }
64 /* A Method that calculates the homogenous transformation
65  * matrix to rotate from S_i to S_0 (S means koordinates / S_0 are world
66  * coordinates).
67  * It basically finds a way how the current coordinates need to be rotated to
68  * fit
69  * in the global context, based on driven distance and steering values.
70  */
71 Eigen::Matrix4d* ForwardKinematics::calcRot(double theta, double alpha)
72 {
73  Eigen::Matrix4d* rot = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
74  *rot = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
75 
76  if (alpha > 0)
77  {
78  (*rot)(0, 0) = flattenZeros(std::cos(theta));
79  (*rot)(0, 1) = flattenZeros(-std::sin(theta));
80  (*rot)(1, 0) = flattenZeros(std::sin(theta));
81  (*rot)(1, 1) = flattenZeros(std::cos(theta));
82  }
83  else
84  {
85  (*rot)(0, 0) = flattenZeros(std::cos(-theta));
86  (*rot)(0, 1) = flattenZeros(-std::sin(-theta));
87  (*rot)(1, 0) = flattenZeros(std::sin(-theta));
88  (*rot)(1, 1) = flattenZeros(std::cos(-theta));
89  }
90 
91  return rot;
92 }
93 /* Here we do not need to make assumptions about the cars orientation, with
94  * the help
95  * of steering values. In this method only the Gyroscopes measurements are used
96  * to rotate our car correctly.
97 */
98 Eigen::Matrix4d* ForwardKinematics::calcRotWithGyro(double theta)
99 {
100  Eigen::Matrix4d* rot = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
101  *rot = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
102 
103  (*rot)(0, 0) = flattenZeros(std::cos(theta));
104  (*rot)(0, 1) = flattenZeros(-std::sin(theta));
105  (*rot)(1, 0) = flattenZeros(std::sin(theta));
106  (*rot)(1, 1) = flattenZeros(std::cos(theta));
107 
108  return rot;
109 }
110 /* A Method that calculates the homogenous transformation
111  * matrix to translate from S_i to S_0 (S means koordinates / S_0 are world
112  * coordinates).
113  * It basically finds a way how the current coordinates need to be shifted to
114  * fit
115  * in the global contextm, based on driven distance and steering values.
116  */
117 Eigen::Matrix4d* ForwardKinematics::calcTrans(double radius, double distance,
118  double alpha,
119  std::pair<double, double> ICC)
120 {
121  Eigen::Matrix4d* trans = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
122  *trans = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
123  double x;
124  double y;
125 
126  if (alpha == 0)
127  {
128  x = 0;
129  y = distance;
130  }
131  else
132  {
133  double theta = calcTheta(distance, radius);
134 
135  if (alpha > 0)
136  {
137  x = radius * std::cos(theta + alpha) + ICC.first;
138  y = radius * std::sin(theta + alpha) + ICC.second;
139  }
140  else
141  {
142  x = radius * std::cos(PI - theta + alpha) + ICC.first;
143  y = radius * std::sin(PI - theta + alpha) + ICC.second;
144  }
145  }
146  (*trans)(0, 3) = flattenZeros(x);
147  (*trans)(1, 3) = flattenZeros(y);
148 
149  return trans;
150 }
151 /* Here we do not need to make assumptions about the cars position, with
152  * the help
153  * of steering values. In this method only the Gyroscopes measurements are used
154  * to move our car correctly, since were driving on circles.
155 */
156 Eigen::Matrix4d* ForwardKinematics::calcTransWithGyro(double theta, double dS)
157 {
158  Eigen::Matrix4d* trans = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
159  *trans = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
160 
161  double x = std::sin(theta) * dS;
162  double y = std::cos(theta) * dS;
163 
164  (*trans)(0, 3) = flattenZeros(x);
165  (*trans)(1, 3) = flattenZeros(y);
166 
167  return trans;
168 }
169 /* Here all of the functions from above are combined (except the ones that
170  * calculate
171  * with Gyroscope values). In this Method we take the old position as our new
172  * base
173  * coordinates and add our new driven path and rotation. Then transformation
174  * matrices
175  * are used to transform the new coordinates in world coordinates.
176  */
177 std::vector<double> ForwardKinematics::getUpdate(double alpha, double distance)
178 {
179  Eigen::Matrix4d* Ti = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
180  *Ti = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
181 
182  if (alpha == 0)
183  {
184  Ti = calcTrans(0, distance, alpha, std::make_pair(0, 0));
185  }
186  else
187  {
188  std::pair<double, double> ICC = calcICC(alpha);
189  double radius = calcRadius(ICC);
190  double theta = calcTheta(distance, radius);
191 
192  Ti = calcRot(theta, alpha);
193  Eigen::Matrix4d* trans = calcTrans(radius, distance, alpha, ICC);
194  *Ti = (*trans) * (*Ti);
195  delete trans;
196  }
197 
198  Eigen::Matrix4d Tn = prevT * (*Ti);
199  delete Ti;
200 
201  prevT = Tn;
202 
203  double x = Tn(0, 3);
204  double y = Tn(1, 3);
205  double e_x1 = Tn(0, 0);
206  double e_x2 = Tn(1, 0);
207  double angle = std::atan2(e_x2, e_x1) / (2 * PI) * 360;
208 
209  currentPosition[0] = flattenZeros(x);
210  currentPosition[1] = flattenZeros(y);
211  currentPosition[2] = angle;
212 
213  return currentPosition;
214 }
215 /* Here all of the functions from above are combined (except the ones that don't
216  * calculate
217  * with Gyroscope values). In this Method we take the old position as our new
218  * base
219  * coordinates and add our new driven path and rotation. Then transformation
220  * matrices
221  * are used to transform the new coordinates in world coordinates.
222  */
223 std::vector<double> ForwardKinematics::getUpdateWithGyro(double theta,
224  double deltaS)
225 {
226  Eigen::Matrix4d* Ti = new Eigen::Matrix4d();
227  *Ti = Eigen::Matrix4d::Identity();
228 
229  double deltaTheta = theta - currentPosition[2] * PI / 180;
230 
231  Ti = calcRotWithGyro(deltaTheta);
232  Eigen::Matrix4d* trans = calcTransWithGyro(deltaTheta, deltaS);
233  *Ti = (*trans) * (*Ti);
234 
235  Eigen::Matrix4d Tn = prevT * (*Ti);
236  delete Ti;
237 
238  prevT = Tn;
239 
240  double x = Tn(0, 3);
241  double y = Tn(1, 3);
242  double e_x1 = Tn(0, 0);
243  double e_x2 = Tn(1, 0);
244  double angle = std::atan2(e_x2, e_x1) / (2 * PI) * 360;
245 
246  currentPosition[0] = flattenZeros(x);
247  currentPosition[1] = flattenZeros(y);
248  currentPosition[2] = angle;
249 
250  return currentPosition;
251 }
